content: ...then next major will be Backdrop 2.0.0, which would be a new 2.x branch ...not until many years from now. @cptX see https://backdropcms.org/roadmap
Backdrop 2.0 will NOT be released before January 15th, 2024.
And upgrading to Backdrop 2.0 will be straightforward or we will end with a dead updated site like drupal?

Also @cptX do note that not all open issues that are "slated" for the 1.18.2 milestone need to be fixed. ...when we decide that we need to release 1.18.2, we'll include all merged fixes, and then move any open issues to the next bug fix milestone 1.18.3

Re Backdrop 2.0, there may be some breaking changes, but see this:

Backdrop version 1 will continue to be supported until Backdrop version 3 is released.
We don't plan to include "major" changes in our architecture, like what happened with D8 (you know, switching to composer/symfony etc.)

...see https://backdropcms.org/philosophy and note our #1 principle:

Easier updates: Backwards compatibility is important.

Yes but in order to switch to BD 3 you need to first convert to BD 2. So I'm not sure if it will possible to upgrade to BD 3 directly. Anyway I thought Backdrop's strategy is to have future compatibility so I hope transition to BD 2 will not be so hard.

I understand though that major enhancements require major changes
Jumping to too many off topics now but just a last question. Is it in the milestone the plan to include a cache de-validation mechanism to use for the logged in users as D8 is doing, so caching only parts of the page that haven't changed?

I imagine that there will be some work required, and we will automate things as much as possible. If it makes you feel a bit better about it, we have been developing new features in 1.x since 2013, which will make it 10+ years in 2024 (if we don't push 2.x even further into the future).
I had a lot of frustration with D8/D9 evolvement and unfortunately I have an active site still running Drupal 6. Was too hard to convert to D8/D9. Now I hope I'll successfully convert it to BD
